ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Thorough understanding of a wide range of topics in Kant's body of work, as well as some secondary materials and responses to Kant in the later stages of the course.
I gained a better understanding of Immanuel Kant and why his contributions are still relevant in our times.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Fantastic course. Potentially, some of the non-core writings could be substituted for work on secondary materials that could accompany canonical pieces.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would highly recommend this course for students interested in gaining a complete picture of Kant's philosophy. Understanding how Kant ties morality, freedom, law, and the state together is a rewarding task, and one that fundamentally changes your approach to everyday encounters with these topics.
Absolutely. Professor Pogge is a wonderful instructor who makes the contributions of Kant, Mill, and others relatable in today's society.
